tabs.caption: An overview of the principles and meaning of Yoga within the Jain tradition.

tabData.tagHTML: Yoga is a systematic effort to balance and direct various levels of one's own energy for self-perfection. It represents the profound union of the human individual with its existence, encompassing not just the physical body but the entire being, including intellectual and emotional processes. It is a science that facilitates communication with one's body, mind, and soul, laying the foundation for purity in actions, emotions, and intellect.
The Meaning of Yoga in Jain Tradition
In Jain philosophy, 'Yoga' holds several interconnected meanings:

• Any activity or intention that aids the soul in achieving liberation.
  • Any activity that purifies the mind by freeing it from attachment and aversion. This view, propounded by Ächärya Haribhadra-suri and Ächärya Amitagati, emphasizes practicing the Three Jewels: Right Faith, Right Knowledge, and Right Conduct.
  • The activity of the body, speech, and mind which creates vibration in the soul. As stated by Ächärya Umäsvämi, this activity (yoga) is the channel for the influx of Karma. Auspicious intentions lead to merit (punya), while inauspicious intentions lead to demerit (päp).
  • In a simpler sense, Yoga is also used for Dhyän, which means meditation or contemplation.

The ultimate goal of all paths of Yoga is to arrive at the liberating Truth, Beatitude, and Infinity. It is the realization of the true human potential and the God/Self within. At the final liberating state, all paths merge into a singular experience of the soul's ultimate spiritual quality.

tabs.caption: Indian traditions define four primary paths that lead a worldly soul to liberation.

tabData.title: The Four Primary Paths to Liberation

items.content: This path focuses on achieving supreme Love and Bliss through devotion, surrender, prayers, and rituals. It's excellent for emotionally-oriented individuals, as it helps develop humility and dissolve the ego.

Aimed at intellectually-oriented people, this path uses study, thinking, direct inquiry, and contemplation. It seeks to discriminate between what is real (true reality) and what is unreal (mithyätva). Both Jainism and Buddhism primarily use this path.

This is the yoga of selfless service (social work, environmental protection, education, etc.) for the benefit of all living beings. It is for action-oriented people and is practiced without expecting any results, which helps to dissolve the ego.

items.header: Ashtanga Yoga (Path of Self Control and Meditation)
items.content: This is the science of physical and mental control, aiming for the liberation and perfection of the body and mind. Instituted by Sage Patanjali and sanctioned by Jain Ächäryas like Haribhadra-suri, it consists of eight distinct steps or 'limbs'.

tabs.caption: A hierarchical view of the eight-fold path of Self Control and Meditation.

tabData.title: The Eight Limbs of Ashtanga Yoga
tabData.description: Ashtanga Yoga is a structured path consisting of eight limbs, progressing from social ethics to the highest state of consciousness.

tabs.caption: In Jainism, rituals are performed using two primary forms of Yoga.

tabData.title: The Forms of Yoga in Jain Rituals

items.content: This involves the physical aspects of a ritual. It is comprised of two parts: Äsan Yoga, which is adopting the proper physical posture to nurture and strengthen thoughts, and Varna Yoga, which is the proper pronunciation of scriptural phrases (Sutras) to fortify feelings. Together, they are also known as Käya Yoga (Yoga of the body).

This involves the internal reflection during a ritual. It is also called Mana Yoga (Yoga of the mind) and has three progressive forms: Artha Yoga (understanding the meaning of the phrases), Älamban Yoga (generating feelings based on the meaning), and Nirälamban Yoga (pure meditation where external awareness merges with consciousness).

Truthfulness; being in harmony with mind, speech, and action according to truth.
Non-stealing; a restraint against greed and envy.
Celibacy; avoiding all sensual pleasures to bring one closer to the soul.
Non-possessiveness; not accumulating worldly objects driven by greed.
The five individual observances or disciplines for self-control.
Purity, both external (body) and internal (mind, intellect, speech).
Contentment; maintaining equanimity regardless of external causes.
Austerity; the power to withstand physical discomforts and practice meditation.
Study of the self, consisting of scriptural studies and introspection.
Dedication of all actions to the Divine without expectation of reward.
